doc.repnme: Russia's newly privatized firms : heading in the right direction - but uncertainty hampers restructuring efforts
doc.abstracts: This Note reports the findings from a survey of newly privatized, medium-size and large Russian firms. The survey showed that many firms are making changes and are on the right track; the managers are on the whole very good; and the speed of change is about as fast as could be expected given the starting point, the lack of capital, and the uncertainty in the economic environment. The biggest problems facing these firms were delayed payments from customers, high taxes, insufficient working capital, weak demand and falling orders, inadequate funds for investment, and inflation. These problems were interrelated. For the future, staying afloat will depend critically on: 1) firms' ability to maintain adequate working capital; 2) managers' skills in making strategically correct choices about products and markets; 3) the degree of freedom managers can exercise to downsize in such areas as labor and social assets; 4) the speed with which external competition strikes; and 5) in the longer term, the availability of capital for restructuring. Underpinning all these factors is the rate at which the economy stabilizes. Each step deeper into recession and each percentage point of inflation diminish these firms' chances of survival. But if economy stabilizes and capital is available, many firms in the survey should do well.
